title: Childhood sweethearts fight for more time together after brain tumour shock just year since reunion
text:

A couple of childhood sweethearts are fighting to get a few more years together after one was diagnosed with a shock brain tumour shortly after they were reunited. 
Chris McGregor, 33, has been struggling to recover since he received the devastating news in 2013. 
Partner Lauren Rigby said the diagnosis came less than a year after the pair began dating, having been reunited for the first time since their early teens. 
Heartbreaking photos show Chris, a forklift driver and doorman from Speke, as a young boy with his arm around baby Lauren, now 28, as their mums were close friends. Chris McGregor, as a young boy, and Lauren Rigby, the baby in the middle (Photo: Lauren Rigby) Read More 'Oh yes your father died': Stepmum told children of dad's passing via FACEBOOK 'then buried him in garden' 
Now Lauren is appealing for help paying for treatment in Germany using laser surgery that she said could give him more time with her and his son, Wade, from a previous relationship. 
She said NHS surgeons had successfully removed much of the tumour but could not get all of it without risking serious brain damage, the Liverpool Echo reports. 
His astrocytoma tumour will also continue to grow and could become cancerous in future. Chris McGregor before his operation (Photo: Lauren Rigby) Chris McGregor after an operation (Photo: Lauren Rigby) 
Lauren, a training course designer from Hale, said sufferers with a similar diagnosis were usually given ten years, but said she took hope from some cases of people living longer. 
She said: “It’s heartbreaking to think the person you fall in love with and dreamed of having family with is being eaten alive inside, and that I can’t physically help him. 
“We met at his mum’s funeral, having not seen each other since we were kids. About nine months into our relationship he was diagnosed. A fundraising page has been set up to help (Photo: Lauren Rigby) Read More Touching photos show 'twin who died in womb watching over brother as he grows up without him' 
“We can’t wait until this type of surgery comes here. But it would give him the opportunity to see his son finish school, give his son memories, and I can’t imagine life without him.” 
She wrote on the gofundme.com page: “He spent two weeks looking like Mr Bump. He got words muddled and even made up some new ones. Chris McGregor with his son (Photo: Lauren Rigby) 
“He would forget he had put the bath on or even if he had taken his medication. I heartbreakingly watched the soft, gentle giant, kind man I love become an anxious, shy loner.” 
But she added: “There has been such generosity from family and from people we have never met. He’s finding chemo really difficult, but the sense people want to help him has really picked him up.”
